widget_utils¶

Functions¶

def centerWidgetOnCurrentScreen()

def centerWidgetOnCursor()

def centerWidgetOnParentContents()

def centerWidgetOnParentFrame()

def centerWidgetOnPrimaryScreen()

def centerWidgetOnScreen()

def centerWidgetOnScreenWithCursor()

def retain()

def retainAndReturn()

Description¶

General purpose utility functions relating to Qt widgets.

Windows¶

A widget that has the PySide2.QtCore.Qt.Window flag set is considered a window.

  • A widget that has no parent will always have this flag set.
  • A widget that is constructed with a parent will not have this flag set, unless the widget is a special window type such as PySide2.QtWidgets.QDialog or PySide2.QtWidgets.QMainWindow.
  • This flag will always be unset upon reparenting a widget.
  • It is possible to manually set this flag on any widget via PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget.setWindowFlag().

Coordinates¶

The local coordinates of a window are always defined relative to the primary screen (ie. global coordinates) even if it has a parent. The local coordinates of a non-window are always defined relative to its parent. This behaviour must be considered when making use of the following methods:

  • PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget.x()
  • PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget.y()
  • PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget.pos()
  • PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget.move()
  • PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget.geometry()
  • PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget.frameGeometry()
  • PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget.setGeometry()
  • PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget.mapFromParent()
  • PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget.mapToParent()

References¶

When referencing c++ widgets (ie. those not created by the Qt Python bindings), it is necessary to take certain precautions:

  • The reference should be retrieved dynamically when needed (never cache a reference).
  • If an ancestor is accessed, its reference must be retained until the descendant reference is no longer needed. See retain().
  • If a utility function requires access to the ancestors of an input, it should consider whether it is invalidating the input within the calling scope.

When referencing a descendant of a c++ ancestor widget, the lifetime of any reference to the descendant becomes dependant upon the lifetime of the ancestor reference. It appears that the lifetime of references to descendants are managed through some kind of shared pointer held by the ancestor.

Example:

The following demonstrates the necessity for dynamically retrieving references to c++ widgets between idle states.

def foo():
    # The lifetime of any `menu` reference is now dependant upon the below `window` reference
    window = msTools.coreUI.maya.inspect_utils.getMainWindow()
    menu = window.findChild(QtWidgets.QMenu)

window = msTools.coreUI.maya.inspect_utils.getMainWindow()
menu = window.findChild(QtWidgets.QMenu) # <- Cach a reference

# idle...... (the user invokes `foo`)

menu.objectName() # <- ERROR, the `foo` references were not retained
msTools.coreUI.qt.widget_utils.centerWidgetOnCurrentScreen(widget, xOffset=0, yOffset=0)¶

Center a widget on its current screen (the screen which contains its center position).

Parameters:
  • widget (T <= PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget) – Widget to center.
  • xOffset (int, optional) – Horizontal offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
  • yOffset (int, optional) – Vertical offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
msTools.coreUI.qt.widget_utils.centerWidgetOnCursor(widget, xOffset=0, yOffset=0)¶

Center a widget on the cursor.

Parameters:
  • widget (T <= PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget) – Widget to center.
  • xOffset (int, optional) – Horizontal offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
  • yOffset (int, optional) – Vertical offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
msTools.coreUI.qt.widget_utils.centerWidgetOnParentContents(widget, xOffset=0, yOffset=0)¶

Center a widget on the contents of its parent (this excludes the window frame of the parent).

If the widget does not have a parent, it will be centered on its current screen.

Parameters:
  • widget (T <= PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget) – Widget to center.
  • xOffset (int, optional) – Horizontal offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
  • yOffset (int, optional) – Vertical offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
msTools.coreUI.qt.widget_utils.centerWidgetOnParentFrame(widget, xOffset=0, yOffset=0)¶

Center a widget on its parent (this includes the window frame of the parent).

If the widget does not have a parent, it will be centered on its current screen (the screen which contains its center position).

Parameters:
  • widget (T <= PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget) – Widget to center.
  • xOffset (int, optional) – Horizontal offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
  • yOffset (int, optional) – Vertical offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
msTools.coreUI.qt.widget_utils.centerWidgetOnPrimaryScreen(widget, xOffset=0, yOffset=0)¶

Center a widget on the primary (or default) screen.

Parameters:
  • widget (T <= PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget) – Widget to center.
  • xOffset (int, optional) – Horizontal offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
  • yOffset (int, optional) – Vertical offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
msTools.coreUI.qt.widget_utils.centerWidgetOnScreen(widget, screen, xOffset=0, yOffset=0)¶

Center a widget on a given screen.

Parameters:
  • widget (T <= PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget) – Widget to center.
  • screen (int | PySide2.QtGui.QScreen) –

    Screen represented by either:

    • A screen number if the available Qt bindings reference a version < Qt5.
    • A screen object if the available Qt bindings reference a version >= Qt5.
  • xOffset (int, optional) – Horizontal offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
  • yOffset (int, optional) – Vertical offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
Raises:
  • TypeError – If the available Qt bindings reference a version < Qt5 and screen is not an int.
  • TypeError – If the available Qt bindings reference a version >= Qt5 and screen is not a PySide2.QtGui.QScreen object.
msTools.coreUI.qt.widget_utils.centerWidgetOnScreenWithCursor(widget, xOffset=0, yOffset=0)¶

Center a widget on the screen which contains the cursor.

Parameters:
  • widget (T <= PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget) – Widget to center.
  • xOffset (int, optional) – Horizontal offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
  • yOffset (int, optional) – Vertical offset from the center. Defaults to 0.
msTools.coreUI.qt.widget_utils.retain(widget)¶

Retain a reference to a Qt widget within a global registry.

Note

It is sometimes necessary to retain a reference to an ancestral widget to ensure the descendant reference is not invalidated. See References and the below example.

Parameters:widget (T <= PySide2.QtWidgets.QWidget) – Widget to retain.

Example

def foo():
    window = msTools.coreUI.maya.inspect_utils.getMainWindow()
    widget = window.findChildren(QtWidgets.QMenu)[0] # <- Descendant widget created via c++
    accessParent(widget)
    widget.objectName() # <- ERROR (`widget` reference is invalidated)

def accessParent(widget):
    widget.parent() # <- We have not taken ownership of the parent

foo()

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------

def foo():
    window = msTools.coreUI.maya.inspect_utils.getMainWindow()
    widget = window.findChildren(QtWidgets.QMenu)[0] # <- Descendant widget created via c++
    accessParent(widget)
    widget.objectName() # <- NO ERROR

def accessParent(widget):
    retain(widget.parent()) # <- We have taken ownership of the parent reference

foo()
msTools.coreUI.qt.widget_utils.retainAndReturn(widget)¶

Wrapper of retain() that returns the given widget after retaining a global reference.
